7 hours ago, lextacy said:

For those who are devestated by the staging in VAB ovehaul being cut from the release , I have a inteirm solution for you guys.

 

1. Make your payload in a seperate .craft file.

2. Make note of the # of stages your payload is.

3. Drop this as a subassembly

4. Open/Make up your launcher craft in a new file

5. Leave the amount of stages in step #2 above all your launcher stages

 

I will have to remember this for when I start playing again!

7 hours ago, EwingKang said:

 

WoooooooHooooooo!!!
It's great to know that a science station or surface base would work as a player would expect!
 

It's always Devnote Wednesday for us who live in the Ease hemisphere (and Thrusday edition occationally). Even though I don't really have time to play the game since a few months ago (also working on my thesis too), the devnotes are still the must-haves for each week. You've made my day. THANKYOU!

 

2 hours ago, _stilgar_ said:

This is awesome! One of the things I'd be waiting for in 1.1. 

I'll finally be able to build massive Science Ships, slowly cruising through the Kerbol system, producing lots and lots of science (one big ship with 12 labs sounds like more fun than 12 ships with one)

This is the one obligatory nagging point I tend to have with most updates.

Because THIS player would not expect simple measurement data (from thermometers e.g.) to get lost by uploading them into a labs computer.

Quote

When you fill up your first lab and still have data to spare, that data now properly “bounces” to the next one. To balance out this change, the data is no longer copied, but actually physically sent to the lab. This means that if you want to fill three labs, you need three sets of data. If you recover a lab that has science in it, that science is also properly recovered.

My guess is Squad changed the way it works as follows and for the presumed reasons:

The restriction that labs can only process a certain experiment once has been dropped in favor of being able to fill the data storage of multiple labs in a single craft, data overflowing from one lab to the next should the storage of the former be filled.
The stored experiment is then deleted/lost for balancing reasons (one experiment of 500 data value could fill a ship/station with any number of labs to the brim [it always could, you "just" had to undock every lab to do so]) and because there is no way to control which lab should process an experiment/receive the data points.
With the new system you can dock your expedition ship to your science station with x number of labs in orbit and process away until every lab has its data storage filled to capacity without giving it any more thought.

Problem 1: While in the old system you could process an experiment and then return/transmit it for its direct science value, the experiment is now lost and requires the player to bring back more than one(+) copy of an experiment should he wish to process and return it.

Problem 2: Docking a probe with 200 thermometers/200 instances of the same experiment to said station can be used to fill quite a few labs depending on where this probe took its 200 identical readings.

Solution 1: Processing an experiment on a craft with multiple labs invalidates uploading the same experiment to any and all of the labs that were part of the craft at this time.
But: This would make multiple science stations/bases with just one lab more attractive again. A multiple-labs-station would only offer an easier way to work with science, though the absolute amount of science from processing the experiments from an expedition is severly cut down relative to the old system.

Solution 2: Processing experiments requires them to be moved into the lab first, data spillage fills the next available labs storage.
But: This would make a station with ten labs a real hassle to operate, as the only way to move experiments in stock KSP is by EVA.
Also processing an experiment of 50 data value in a lab with only 1 point of data capacity left could be used to fill the second lab with 99 data points (49 from overflow, 50 from first time processing in this lab).
Invalidating an experiment for every lab that received any amount of data from it - feels like a coder-breaker issue.

Verdict: Solution 1 seems to be the best option here. It completely removes Problem 2. Regarding Problem 1, the multiple labs still offer easier operation of multiple labs and presumably faster science production by simultaneously working in these labs.
Perfectionist players can still use the dock-undock procedure or built multiple science stations/bases to get the most out of a single experiment.
Economical players may still use a lab onboard their expedition craft and process the whole load of experiments at the science station back home before landing a capsule for the return science value.

And now I am damn curious how Arsonide really set up the new system in detail!

Edited February 24, 2016 by KerbMav

10 minutes ago, KerbMav said:

My guess is Squad changed the way it works as follows and for the presumed reasons:

I think it's implemented like this:

Lab 1 has 460 data points, lab 2 is empty. If you want to process an experiment that has 60 data point value, it will go to the second lab, because it won't fit in the first one. 

I don't think they will cut the data points into 40/10 split between the labs. This is how I interpret the "it bounces to next lab" phrase

3 minutes ago, KerbMav said:

This is the one obligatory nagging point I tend to have with most updates.

Because THIS player would not expect simple measurement data (from thermometers e.g.) to get lost by uploading them into a labs computer.

My guess is Squad changed the way it works as follows and for the presumed reasons:

The restriction that labs can only process a certain experiment once has been dropped in favor of being able to fill the data storage of multiple labs in a single craft, data overflowing from one lab to the next should the storage of the former be filled.

No, this is not being changed. Labs can still only process one of each kind of experiment data. The data "bouncing" refers to the fact that in 1.0.5, if you have five labs on your ship, and you fill the first one with data, you will get an error that your lab is full, and not be able to utilize your other labs. This has been fixed.

Data doesn't flow in partial amounts between the labs either. If the experiment data will not fit in the current lab, it will try the next. If it will not fit in any labs, it will tell you that now. The only functional difference here is that storing data in the lab does not produce a copy of said data. Once it goes to the lab, it disappears, so if you want to fill multiple labs you will need to get multiple sets of data. This was done for balance purposes. If the copy behavior remained, then you could take one surface sample, send copies to twenty labs, and still keep the sample when you were done.  This was a bit overpowered to say the least, but it wasn't a problem prior to multiple labs being fixed.

Hopefully this clears things up a bit!

1 minute ago, _stilgar_ said:

I don't think they will cut the data points into 40/10 split between the labs. This is how I interpret the "it bounces to next lab" phrase

I think that is exactly what happens though.

Quote

When you fill up your first lab and still have data to spare, that data now properly “bounces” to the next one.

Funny questions: What happens should the player undock the second lab at any point during processing?

1 minute ago, KerbMav said:

Funny questions: What happens should the player undock the second lab at any point during processing?

Same thing happens now when you process two experiments at the same time - it says that there is no room to store data and stops. 

Or Kraken appears and destroys your ship. 

5 minutes ago, Arsonide said:

Hopefully this clears things up a bit! 

This works exactly as I hoped it would. Thank you so much!

35 minutes ago, Arsonide said:

Hopefully this clears things up a bit! 

It does, thank you.

Hmmm ... Asteroid and Surface Samples, Mystery Goo, Science Jr. and Atmo-Analysis (if seen as a gas sample) vanishing in the lab work for me, but the other four do not bring back anything physical, they just give data which should be infinitely copyable, so transmission for 100% makes sense here. (Which most likely is already the case, and it is just my bad memory and the wiki page being out of date. )

Also, there is finally a really big and good reason for the lab to be able to hold multiple copies of the same experiment! Sure, you could bring three of a kind already, but you still would have to land either multiple crew pods to keep your ship in orbit for another voyage or land the whole thing, well at least the lab. Now we can pack the lab of a ship full of stuff, dock it to our science station at Kerbin, move the whole load over to one of its labs and of you go, processing and finding a place to fit in!

Edited February 24, 2016 by KerbMav

13 hours ago, Mad Rocket Scientist said:

Grab the... Oh, look!  It's on time!  Anyway, nice devnotes!

I'm sure we can find a reason anyway!  Like the poem!  What The Heck?  It sounds like the player set out with the intention of dropping his Kerbonauts into the Sun and the trip to Minmus was just a cover story to keep the audience guessing.  A trip to the surface of the Sun takes a lot more delta-V and time than several trips to Minmus.  And the poem really made it seem malicious!  Poems like this could cause the game to receive that ESRB content descriptor about violence...  Maybe you guys should lay off the poetry and spend your time writing code?    Before anyone tells me to lighten up - that was a joke.

But hey - I am looking forward to trying lextacy's workaround for staging issues.  That may fix one of my big reasons for having stopped playing.  If Squad can fix the performance issues, then I might be happy again!

 

Danny

 

One question about the science lab fix...  Will data "bounce" in discrete chunks or will it be divisible?  What I mean is if we have a ship with three labs capable of storing 500 data each and we complete an experiment that provides 1300 data, will that data be split among our three labs or will we still be unable to process it because it won't all fit in one lab?

 

*** I see Arsonide answered this question already...  thanks for the answer.  Is anything going to be done to accommodate these experiments that return large amounts of data?

5 hours ago, lextacy said:

Does that not use the same set of code as in the VAB? The "bug" has the same exact symptoms inside the VAB as does when you dock/undock and the stages get scrambled.

Without deeper knowledge, I'm pretty sure that's something completely different. The VAB sometimes just ranks stages incorrectly and therefore mixes them up. I think I've actually read about the stage logic being optimized and fixed in a lot of ways? The UI elements certainly had to be rewritten, so there might be some huge improvement.

Said docking issue the devnote is talking about is probably more about two ships having two staging lists that shouldn't be mixed in the first place, but which is unavoidable when they joint to a single entity. So to 'fix' the bug you'd need to have to be able to switch between multiple persistent staging lists for docked vessels, which would require a completely new system to handle stages.

Thinking about it, systems like this would be pretty handy in VAB. Imagine being able to group stages into a box, and being able to move said box around the staging list. Shouldn't even be that complex to integrate, should it?

Edited February 24, 2016 by Temeter

39 minutes ago, CrashTestDanny said:

Is anything going to be done to accommodate these experiments that return large amounts of data?

You mean those 500+ data ones? Totally forgot about those.

The amount of available data could have no/less/variable influence on the science generation speed to allow for more preloaded data points. This would negate at least one argument for the low capacity and at the same time solve the niche but existing problem of big chunks of data from some experiments.

I would go for a physical release in a heartbeat over digi but I didn't/don't expect it to be offered.

34 minutes ago, KerbMav said:

You mean those 500+ data ones? Totally forgot about those.

The amount of available data could have no/less/variable influence on the science generation speed to allow for more preloaded data points. This would negate at least one argument for the low capacity and at the same time solve the niche but existing problem of big chunks of data from some experiments.

Looking at the Science Wiki, there should only be 2 groups that can top 500 science in one experiment in the stock game:

1) Asteroid samples(70 data) from outside the orbit of Dres(Jool system(up to 700 data from flying low on Lathe) or Eeloo(up to 1050 data landed))
2) Surface samples(40 data) from Eeloo(600 data)

While it would be nice if there was an answer to this issue, I must admit that I have difficulty imagining a space program that can get Kerbals to Eeloo(for surface samples) or asteroids to Jool/Eeloo with a Kerbal on hand to take samples, that has not already finished just about any tech tree they might like to use...

(I am sure a tech tree could be assembled that requires every last bit of data that could be harvested in the Kerbol system Plus a hefty dose from labs, but even then, just topping off your lab from the Kerbin system before you head out to Jool/Eeloo could net you at least as much during your trip as those experiments would add once you got here...)

 

It sounds like the ability to use a lab as a storage depot for multiple copies of experiments(like 4x goo, materials and surface samples from each biome) will remain intact, and may become even more valuble as you will want an extra copy or two of each experiment for converting to lab data as well.

 

Although that does remind me, last time I used the science->rep strategy, I could recover lots and lots of science but my rep never moved.  I even checked my total rep points by saving and spending lots of rep on other strategies, and the total number of points did not go up.  (I think this was 1.0.3)  Anyone know if this is working in stock 1.0.5?(I had several mods so it may or may not have been working in stock at that point)

@NathanKell what changes if any have been made to the dockingNode module? I'm starting to work on some now and I wanted to know if there was anything I should be aware of.

Edited February 24, 2016 by CobaltWolf
I love the poem it's awesome. I hope more o them will be created!

2 hours ago, llanthas said:

Yeah, it's incredibly hard to play any sort of game on a laptop without Dedicated graphics.  

Dedicated Graphics means that there is a separate video card in there, doing its thing.  The alternative option is Integrated Graphics, which means that your motherboard is processing the graphics itself.  Manufacturers use special names for them like "Intel HD 500" or whatever to fool you, but you just need to do a quick google of the card to see what it is. 

If you're shopping online, there's usually an option to filter for a laptop with Dedicated Graphics.  Alternatively, pretty much any card made by Nvidia is a Dedicated option.  Always best to google it before a purchase though. 

Does that mean it's impossible to get KSP to work properly on my laptop? Can't I just get a new card?

3 minutes ago, Mitchz95 said:

Does that mean it's impossible to get KSP to work properly on my laptop? Can't I just get a new card?

I don't think there's an option to replace if you have integrated graphics. I still think the graphics card is less important than the processor. My current laptop with integrated graphics but an i7 processor runs a whole lot cooler than the previous one with a dedicated graphics card but a far less powerful processor. Not that I play KSP on the laptop anymore; I got a desktop machine for that which can run KSP without revving up the fans.
